title: NIPS_2015_18_abs

sentences.text: Many practical modeling problems involve discrete data that are best represented as draws from multinomial or categorical distributions .
For example , nucleotides in a DNA sequence , children 's names in a given state and year , and text documents are all commonly modeled with multinomial distributions .

In all of these cases , we expect some form of dependency between the draws : the nucleotide at one position in the DNA strand may depend on the preceding nucleotides , children 's names are highly correlated from year to year , and topics in text may be correlated and dynamic .
These dependencies are not naturally captured by the typical Dirichlet-multinomial formulation .

Here , we leverage a logistic stick-breaking representation and recent innovations in Pólya-gamma augmentation to reformu-late the multinomial distribution in terms of latent variables with jointly Gaussian likelihoods , enabling us to take advantage of a host of Bayesian inference techniques for Gaussian models with minimal overhead .

Entity-these_dependency.label: These dependencies
Entity-these_dependency.description: These dependencies refer to the correlations and relationships between discrete draws from multinomial or categorical distributions, such as the influence of preceding nucleotides in DNA sequences or the temporal correlation of children's names, which are inadequately modeled by the standard Dirichlet-multinomial approach.

Entity-dependency.label: dependencies
Entity-dependency.description: In the context of the paper, 'dependencies' refer to the relationships or correlations between discrete data draws, such as those found in multinomial or categorical distributions, which are not adequately modeled by traditional Dirichlet-multinomial approaches.

Entity-modeling_problem.label: modeling problems
Entity-modeling_problem.description: Modeling problems refer to statistical challenges in representing discrete data, such as nucleotide sequences or text documents, using multinomial or categorical distributions while accounting for dependencies among the data points.

Entity-the_typical_dirichlet-multinomial.label: the typical Dirichlet-multinomial formulation
Entity-the_typical_dirichlet-multinomial.description: The typical Dirichlet-multinomial formulation refers to a statistical model used to represent discrete data as draws from multinomial distributions, which does not adequately account for dependencies between the draws in various practical applications.

Entity-many_practical_modeling_problem.label: Many practical modeling problems
Entity-many_practical_modeling_problem.description: Many practical modeling problems refer to various real-world scenarios where discrete data is represented as samples from multinomial or categorical distributions, often exhibiting dependencies among the data points.

Entity-dirichlet-multinomial.label: Dirichlet-multinomial
Entity-dirichlet-multinomial.description: The Dirichlet-multinomial is a statistical model that generalizes the multinomial distribution by incorporating a Dirichlet prior, allowing for the modeling of overdispersed count data with dependencies among categories.

Entity-plya-gamma.label: Pólya-gamma
Entity-plya-gamma.description: Pólya-gamma refers to a mathematical concept used in statistics, particularly in Bayesian inference, that involves a specific type of distribution which facilitates the augmentation of models for improved computational efficiency.

Entity-plya-gamma_augmentation.label: Pólya-gamma augmentation
Entity-plya-gamma_augmentation.description: Pólya-gamma augmentation is a statistical technique used in Bayesian methods to facilitate the sampling and inference of latent variables by transforming certain distributions into forms that are more amenable to analysis.

Entity-logistic_stick-breaking_represent.label: logistic stick-breaking representation
Entity-logistic_stick-breaking_represent.description: The logistic stick-breaking representation is a statistical model that utilizes a stick-breaking process to construct probability distributions, particularly in the context of latent variable models and Bayesian inference.

Entity-multinomial_distribution.label: multinomial distributions
Entity-multinomial_distribution.description: Multinomial distributions are a class of probability distributions that generalize the binomial distribution to scenarios where there are more than two possible outcomes for each trial, often used to model categorical data.

Entity-multinomial_or_categorical_distri.label: multinomial or categorical distributions
Entity-multinomial_or_categorical_distri.description: Multinomial or categorical distributions are probability distributions that model the outcomes of experiments where each outcome falls into one of several categories, with the multinomial distribution being used for multiple trials and the categorical distribution for a single trial.

Entity-gaussian_model.label: Gaussian models
Entity-gaussian_model.description: Gaussian models are statistical models that assume the data follows a Gaussian (normal) distribution, often used in probability theory and statistics for various applications including Bayesian inference.

Entity-child_s_name_in_a_given_state_and.label: children's names in a given state and year
aliases: children's names in a given state and year
Entity-child_s_name_in_a_given_state_and.description: The term 'children's names in a given state and year' refers to a dataset that captures the frequency and distribution of names given to children born in a specific state during a particular year, which can be analyzed using multinomial or categorical statistical models.

mentions.local_name: children's names in a given state and year

Entity-gaussian_likelihood.label: Gaussian likelihoods
Entity-gaussian_likelihood.description: Gaussian likelihoods refer to a statistical representation of data where the likelihood of observing the data is modeled using a Gaussian (normal) distribution, often used in Bayesian inference and probabilistic modeling.

Entity-jointly_gaussian_likelihood.label: jointly Gaussian likelihoods
Entity-jointly_gaussian_likelihood.description: Jointly Gaussian likelihoods refer to a statistical model where multiple random variables are assumed to follow a Gaussian distribution and are correlated with each other, allowing for the joint probability of these variables to be expressed in terms of their means and covariance structure.

Entity-minimal_overhead.label: minimal overhead
Entity-minimal_overhead.description: Minimal overhead refers to the reduced computational and implementation burden associated with utilizing Bayesian inference techniques for Gaussian models when reformulating multinomial distributions through latent variables.

Entity-categorical_distribution.label: categorical distributions
Entity-categorical_distribution.description: Categorical distributions are a type of probability distribution that describe the likelihood of each possible outcome in a finite set of discrete categories.

Entity-bayesian_inference_technique.label: Bayesian inference techniques
Entity-bayesian_inference_technique.description: Bayesian inference techniques are statistical methods that apply Bayes' theorem to update the probability of a hypothesis as more evidence or information becomes available.

Entity-child_s_name.label: children's names
Entity-child_s_name.description: children's names refer to the given names assigned to individuals who are in the age range typically classified as children.

Entity-latent_variable.label: latent variables
Entity-latent_variable.description: Latent variables are unobserved or hidden variables in statistical models that are inferred from observed data, often used to capture underlying structures or relationships in the data.

Entity-nucleotide_in_a_dna_sequence.label: nucleotides in a DNA sequence
Entity-nucleotide_in_a_dna_sequence.description: Nucleotides in a DNA sequence are the fundamental building blocks of DNA, consisting of four types—adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T)—that encode genetic information and can be modeled as discrete data in statistical frameworks.

Entity-the_nucleotide_at_one_position_in.label: the nucleotide at one position in the DNA strand
aliases: the nucleotide at one position in the DNA strand
Entity-the_nucleotide_at_one_position_in.description: The nucleotide at one position in the DNA strand refers to a specific base (adenine, thymine, cytosine, or guanine) located at a defined location within a DNA sequence, which can exhibit dependencies on the nucleotides that precede it.

mentions.local_name: the nucleotide at one position in the DNA strand

Entity-correlated_and_dynamic.label: correlated and dynamic
Entity-correlated_and_dynamic.description: The term 'correlated and dynamic' refers to the interdependent and evolving relationships among topics in text documents, indicating that the presence and relevance of certain topics can change over time while being influenced by one another.

Entity-the_preceding_nucleotide.label: the preceding nucleotides
Entity-the_preceding_nucleotide.description: The preceding nucleotides refer to the nucleotides in a DNA sequence that come before a specific nucleotide, which may influence its identity or characteristics due to dependencies in the sequence.

Entity-discrete_data.label: discrete data
Entity-discrete_data.description: Discrete data refers to a type of data that can take on a finite number of distinct values, often representing countable quantities or categories.

Entity-dna_strand.label: DNA strand
Entity-dna_strand.description: A DNA strand is a long, linear sequence of nucleotides that encodes genetic information and forms the structural basis of DNA, which is essential for the storage and transmission of hereditary traits in living organisms.

Entity-state.label: state
Entity-state.description: In this context, 'state' refers to a specific geographical region within a country where children's names are analyzed and modeled in relation to the year.

Entity-dna_sequence.label: DNA sequence
Entity-dna_sequence.description: A DNA sequence is a linear arrangement of nucleotides that encodes genetic information in living organisms.

Entity-topic_in_text.label: topics in text
Entity-topic_in_text.description: Topics in text refer to the subjects or themes present within textual data that may exhibit correlations and changes over time.

Entity-nucleotide.label: nucleotides
Entity-nucleotide.description: Nucleotides are the basic building blocks of nucleic acids, such as DNA and RNA, consisting of a nitrogenous base, a sugar molecule, and one or more phosphate groups.

Entity-text_document.label: text documents
Entity-text_document.description: Text documents are written or printed materials that convey information, typically consisting of words and sentences, and can be stored, processed, and analyzed in various formats.

Entity-year_(1).label: year
Entity-year_(1).description: The term 'year' refers to a unit of time that is used to measure the duration of one complete orbit of the Earth around the Sun, often used in the context of analyzing trends and dependencies in data across different time periods.

Entity-year.label: year
Entity-year.description: A year is a unit of time that represents a specific duration, typically consisting of 365 days, used to denote a particular point in the chronological timeline.

summary: Many practical modeling problems involve discrete data that are best represented as draws from multinomial or categorical distributions . For example , nucleotides in a DNA sequence , children 's names in a given state and year , and text documents are all commonly modeled with multinomial distributions . In all of these cases , we expect some form of dependency between the draws : the nucleotide at one position in the DNA strand may depend on the preceding nucleotides , children 's names are highly correlated from year to year , and topics in text may be correlated and dynamic . These dependencies are not naturally captured by the typical Dirichlet-multinomial formulation . Here , we leverage a logistic stick-breaking representation and recent innovations in Pólya-gamma augmentation to reformu-late the multinomial distribution in terms of latent variables with jointly Gaussian likelihoods , enabling us to take advantage of a host of Bayesian inference techniques for Gaussian models with minimal overhead .

Predicate-involve.label: involve
Predicate-involve.description: The predicate 'involve' indicates a relationship where the subject encompasses, requires, or includes the object as a necessary component or aspect. It suggests that the subject cannot be fully understood or realized without considering the object, highlighting a connection where the object plays a significant role in the context of the subject.

Predicate-are_represented_as_draws_from.label: are represented as draws from
Predicate-are_represented_as_draws_from.description: The predicate 'are represented as draws from' indicates that the subject is modeled or conceptualized as originating from a specific statistical distribution or process, which is specified as the object. This implies that the characteristics or behaviors of the subject can be understood in terms of random samples or outcomes generated by the distribution mentioned in the object.

Predicate-modeled_with.label: modeled with
Predicate-modeled_with.description: The predicate 'modeled with' indicates a relationship where the subject is represented or described using the methods, frameworks, or structures provided by the object. It suggests that the subject is being analyzed, simulated, or understood through the lens of the object, which serves as a mathematical or conceptual tool for representation.

Predicate-are_modeled_with.label: are modeled with
Predicate-are_modeled_with.description: The predicate 'are modeled with' indicates a relationship where the subject is represented or described using the methods, frameworks, or structures denoted by the object. It suggests that the subject can be understood or analyzed through the lens of the object, which serves as a mathematical or conceptual tool for representation.

Predicate-depends_on.label: depends on
Predicate-depends_on.description: The predicate 'depends on' indicates a relationship where the subject is influenced, determined, or conditioned by the object. It suggests that the state, behavior, or characteristics of the subject are contingent upon the presence, properties, or actions of the object, establishing a dependency that implies that changes in the object may directly affect the subject.

Predicate-are_correlated.label: are correlated
Predicate-are_correlated.description: The predicate 'are correlated' indicates a relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that changes or variations in the subject are associated with changes or variations in the object. This correlation implies a statistical or conceptual link, where the presence or characteristics of the subject may influence or relate to the characteristics of the object.

Predicate-are_correlated_and_dynamic.label: are correlated and dynamic
Predicate-are_correlated_and_dynamic.description: The predicate 'are correlated and dynamic' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject exhibits a connection characterized by interdependence and changeability. It suggests that the elements represented by the subject not only influence each other but also evolve over time, reflecting a state of interaction that is both interconnected and adaptable.

Predicate-may_depend_on.label: may depend on
Predicate-may_depend_on.description: The predicate 'may depend on' indicates a conditional relationship where the state, behavior, or characteristics of the subject are influenced or determined by the object. It suggests that the subject's properties or outcomes are not fixed but can vary based on the presence, arrangement, or nature of the object, implying a level of uncertainty or variability in this dependence.

Predicate-are_not_captured_by.label: are not captured by
Predicate-are_not_captured_by.description: The predicate 'are not captured by' indicates a relationship where the subject lacks representation, explanation, or inclusion within the framework or model described by the object. It suggests that the characteristics or nuances of the subject are inadequately addressed or overlooked by the object, highlighting a gap or limitation in the object's ability to encompass the subject's complexities.

Predicate-leverage.label: leverage
Predicate-leverage.description: The predicate 'leverage' indicates a relationship where the subject utilizes or takes advantage of the object to enhance its effectiveness, performance, or functionality. In this context, the subject employs the object as a resource or tool to achieve a specific goal or to improve a process.

Predicate-reformulate.label: reformulate
Predicate-reformulate.description: The predicate 'reformulate' indicates a process in which the subject is transformed or expressed in a different way to achieve a new representation or understanding of the object. This often involves altering the structure, parameters, or assumptions associated with the object to facilitate analysis, application, or integration with other concepts.

Predicate-in_terms_of.label: in terms of
Predicate-in_terms_of.description: The predicate 'in terms of' establishes a relationship that specifies the perspective or framework through which the subject is being considered or analyzed in relation to the object. It indicates that the subject is being discussed, evaluated, or defined with respect to the characteristics, properties, or concepts represented by the object.

Predicate-with.label: with
Predicate-with.description: The predicate 'with' indicates a relationship of association or accompaniment between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject is characterized by, or exists in conjunction with, the object. It implies a connection where the subject is enhanced, defined, or influenced by the presence or nature of the object.

Predicate-for.label: for
Predicate-for.description: The predicate 'for' indicates a relationship of purpose, suitability, or application between the subject and the object. It suggests that the subject is intended to be used in relation to, or is particularly relevant to, the object, often implying a functional or contextual connection.

Predicate-are_used_for.label: are used for
Predicate-are_used_for.description: The predicate 'are used for' indicates a functional relationship where the subject serves a specific purpose or application related to the object. It implies that the subject is employed or utilized in a manner that facilitates, supports, or achieves the objectives associated with the object.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject possesses certain characteristics, properties, or attributes represented by the object. In this context, it implies that the subject is defined or characterized by the presence of the object, establishing a connection where the subject can be understood in terms of the object it 'has'.

Predicate-are_inadequately_modeled_by.label: are inadequately modeled by
Predicate-are_inadequately_modeled_by.description: The predicate 'are inadequately modeled by' indicates that the subject lacks sufficient representation or explanation by the object. It suggests that the object fails to capture the complexities, nuances, or essential characteristics of the subject, leading to an incomplete or flawed understanding of the subject's nature or behavior.

Predicate-account_for.label: account for
Predicate-account_for.description: The predicate 'account for' indicates a relationship where the subject provides an explanation, justification, or reason for the existence or occurrence of the object. It implies that the subject plays a significant role in influencing, determining, or contributing to the characteristics or outcomes associated with the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset of the more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider scope or a more inclusive concept that includes the subject within its definition.
